title: 112_hr3210
content: The Act may be cited as the "Retailers and Entertainers Lacey Implementation and Enforcement Fairness Act" or the "RELIEF Act." The 2008 amendments to the Lacey Act aimed to support American businesses in the legal trade of plants but were too broad and could unfairly penalize innocent parties. The 2008 amendments to the Lacey Act may unfairly penalize individuals for unknowingly possessing illegal wood products, leading to concerns about criminal exposure. Sanctions for violations should be proportional, especially for those not in the commercial shipping business. The Department of the Interior and Department of Justice have clarified that individuals who unknowingly possess illegal wood products may not have criminal exposure if they exercised due care. Clarification of the 2008 amendments is necessary. The 2008 amendments to the Lacey Act require clarification to ensure legally harvested new plant products can enter the market. Declaration requirements for plant products imported before May 22, 2008, are deemed unreasonable. Federal law enforcement should avoid overzealous actions. Adequate funding is needed for implementing current declaration phases. Agencies should provide a publicly accessible database on foreign laws related to plant importation. The Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 include a new section 9 that limits the application of the Act to certain plants and plant products. The Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 limit the application of the Act to plants imported before May 22, 2008, or finished plant products processed before that date. Additionally, there are limitations on the plant declaration requirement under Section 3(f) of the Act. The Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 restrict the Act's application to plants imported before May 22, 2008, or finished plant products processed before that date. Amendments include exemptions for plant products derived from trees, with regulations defining "solid wood" for clarity. Civil forfeiture laws under the Act are also modified. SEC. 4 amends the Lacey Act to limit the application of foreign laws directed at plant protection, conservation, and management. Civil penalties under the Act are also modified to reflect this change. Section 3(f) of the Lacey Act (16 U.S.C. 3372(f)) is amended to shorten the timeline for certain reviews and actions by the Secretary and Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. The Lacey Act is amended to shorten review timelines and actions by the Secretary and Director of the US Fish and Wildlife Service. Additionally, an evaluation is required for creating a publicly available database of laws from foreign countries where plants are exported.
